source_node.current_analysis:
The July core PCE gauge rose to 2.6 % year‑on‑year, a figure that sits comfortably above the Fed’s 2 % target but remains below the 2.9 % threshold that would dampen expectations of a rate cut (U21K4ALYQ)(ZUXOHE4Q9).  Fed Chair Jerome Powell’s recent hint that the policy rate could be trimmed by 25 bp in September has pushed market‑based odds of a cut to roughly 85 % according to FedWatch futures (U21K4ALYQ).  The core PCE reading therefore serves as the primary driver of the Fed’s near‑term stance: a reading below 2.9 % reinforces dovish sentiment, while a rise above that level would shift expectations toward a more hawkish outlook (U21K4ALYQ).  

The policy signal translates directly into UST 10‑year pricing.  A Fed cut is expected to flatten the yield curve, pulling the 10‑year down 5–10 bp and compressing the term premium by 3–5 bp (U21K4ALYQ).  Conversely, if core PCE climbs above 2.9 % or political uncertainty materializes, the 10‑year could rise 5–15 bp and the term premium widen 3–6 bp (U21K4ALYQ)(GXYXMKIG5).  The Cook removal lawsuit is a key political catalyst: a court block would reinforce Fed credibility, supporting the dovish narrative and potentially lowering long‑term yields by 5–10 bp, whereas a successful removal would erode confidence and push yields higher by a similar amount (GXYXMKIG5).  The next core PCE release in mid‑September and the Fed’s September FOMC minutes (late‑September) constitute the short‑term catalyst windows that will confirm or refute the current policy trajectory.  If core PCE remains below 2.9 % and the Fed signals a cut, the 10‑year should fall 5–10 bp and the term premium compress 3–5 bp; if PCE rises above 2.9 % or political risk materializes, yields should rise 5–15 bp and the term premium widen 3–6 bp.

source_node.fundamental_analysis:
The 30‑year fixed mortgage rate sits at 6.548 % and has been anchored near 7 % since the Fed began cutting rates in September 2024 (LF0UUL917). Fed policy is the primary lever: a cut in 2025 would lower the 10‑yr Treasury yield (ust10y) and compress the mortgage spread, pushing the rate down by roughly the same amount (BSV8LPNDM). Conversely, a pause or reversal would lift the 10‑yr yield and widen the spread, raising the mortgage rate (BSV8LPNDM). The Fed’s reaction function, focused on keeping inflation near 2 %, underpins this transmission; if inflation spikes, the Fed may pause cuts, raising the 10‑yr yield and mortgage rate (BSV8LPNDM). The current labor‑market strength and fiscal‑deficit trajectory reinforce the Fed’s willingness to keep rates elevated, supporting the mortgage rate’s upper bound (BSV8LPNDM).

Base case: Fed cuts in Q2 2025, 10‑yr yield falls 15 bp, mortgage rate falls to 6.4‑6.5 % (BSV8LPNDM). Upside: earlier cuts in Q1 2025, 10‑yr yield falls 20 bp, mortgage rate falls to 6.3‑6.4 % (BSV8LPNDM). Downside: CPI rises to 3.5 % in July 2025, Fed pauses, 10‑yr yield rises 10 bp, mortgage rate rises to 6.6‑6.7 % (BSV8LPNDM). Watch list: Fed policy statements, monthly CPI/PCE releases, Treasury yield movements, and credit‑spread dynamics (BSV8LPNDM). Confidence: moderate, given the clear transmission channels and the current policy trajectory (LF0UUL917).
source_node.executive_summary: ust10y +5–10 bp (3–6 mo) if the $150 bn defense bill passes in full and the Fed adopts a dovish stance, as fiscal outlays lift long‑term yields while a potential easing of short‑term rates will flatten the curve but leave the 10‑year on a net lift (O6LHRBLFM)(GK86UUQPN). Fed tightening would compress the term structure and could pull the 10‑year down by roughly 5 bp, whereas a recession‑triggered easing could lift it by about 10 bp (GK86UUQPN). Watch the July/August Fed minutes, Q4 2025 defense‑bill funding, 2‑yr/10‑yr spread, and CPI/PCE releases (GK86UUQPN)(O6LHRBLFM)(Z7O1DCHS7)(LF0UUL917). Confidence is moderate, contingent on defense‑bill passage and Fed‑policy trajectory (GK86UUQPN).
source_node.name: US Inflation
source_node.movers_scenarios:
Up | 3‑6 mo | Fed 25‑bp cut on 25 Sep (GK86UUQPN) compresses the 2‑yr/10‑yr spread by 57 bp (Z7O1DCHS7) and lifts 10‑yr yields (LF0UUL917) to support a 0.5–1 % DXY rally (B1KYJ1GPU) | Fed minutes, early‑Aug CPI (LF0UUL917), 2‑yr/10‑yr spread (Z7O1DCHS7) | 70%  
Down | 3‑6 mo | Defense bill not fully passed (O6LHRBLFM) reduces fiscal outlays, dampens long‑term yield lift (O6LHRBLFM) and weakens the dollar’s yield edge, leading to a 0.5–1 % DXY decline (B1KYJ1GPU) | Defense bill passage (O6LHRBLFM), 10‑yr yield trend (O6LHRBLFM) | 30%  
Down | 3‑6 mo | Early‑Aug CPI falls below 2.5 % (LF0UUL917) weakens term premium (LF0UUL917), lowers 10‑yr yields (LF0UUL917) and pressures the dollar to retreat 0.5–1 % (B1KYJ1GPU) | Early‑Aug CPI (LF0UUL917), term premium signal (LF0UUL917) | 30%  
Up | 3‑6 mo | Recession‑triggered rapid Fed easing (GK86UUQPN) steepens the yield curve (Z7O1DCHS7) and lifts 10‑yr yields (LF0UUL917), supporting a 0.5–1 % DXY rally (B1KYJ1GPU) | Labor‑market revisions, Fed minutes (GK86UUQPN), yield curve (Z7O1DCHS7) | 55%
source_node.drivers:
dxy ↑ 0.5–1 % (3–6 mo) if the Fed’s September 25‑bp cut materialises and the early‑August CPI confirms a lower term premium, lifting dollar yields and supporting the DXY rally (B1KYJ1GPU)(XTQIQRP5K)(NIT6JFIQF)(FAN5RYW6T)(LF0UUL917). The causal chain is Fed cut compresses the 2‑yr/10‑yr spread by 57 bp (Z7O1DCHS7)(7XH2DKEKV) and lifts the 10‑yr Treasury yield (LF0UUL917), supporting the DXY rally. The early‑Aug CPI above 2.5 % (LF0UUL917) would reinforce the lower term premium narrative, while a reading below 2.5 % would undermine it. Aug 30 PCE above 3 % (7XH2DKEKV) or a flattening of the 2‑yr/10‑yr spread below 30 bp (7XH2DKEKV) would lift DXY 50–100 bp; conversely, a steepening of 57 bp (Z7O1DCHS7)(7XH2DKEKV) could push DXY down ~200 bp to 95.8 by Aug 31 (Z7O1DCHS7)(7XH2DKEKV).  

Key watch dates include Aug 30 PCE, Aug 31 NFP, early‑Aug CPI, Sept Fed meeting minutes, and the 2‑yr/10‑yr spread. Fed rate‑hike risk (0.2–0.4 %) (LF0UUL917)(7XH2DKEKV) would compress the term premium and stall the DXY rally; a sustained steepening of the Treasury curve (57 bp) (Z7O1DCHS7)(7XH2DKEKV) would weaken the dollar’s yield edge. The 3–6 month upside view is moderate‑high confidence, contingent on the Fed’s September stance and the persistence of a lower term premium narrative.
source_node.medium_analysis:
The 10‑year U.S. Treasury (ust10y) is expected to see a modest upward move over the next three to six months if the newly signed defense bill passes in full and the Federal Reserve adopts a dovish stance. The bill earmarks more than $150 billion for AI, missile defense and cyber‑security (O6LHRBLFM), which will increase fiscal outlays and tend to lift long‑term yields. At the same time, Fed officials—including Powell and Waller—have signaled that higher layoffs and rising unemployment could prompt earlier rate cuts (GK86UUQPN). A fall in short‑term rates would reduce the steepness of the yield curve, but the fiscal stimulus would keep the long‑term curve on a modestly upward trajectory, leading to a net lift in the 10‑year.

An alternative scenario arises if the Fed decides to hold or raise rates in response to persistent inflation (GK86UUQPN). A tightening stance would compress the term structure and could pull the 10‑year down. Conversely, a sharper labor‑market slowdown could trigger a recession that forces rapid Fed easing, which would again lift the 10‑year (GK86UUQPN). Key risks to the base case are: (1) the defense bill may not pass in full (O6LHRBLFM); (2) the Fed may hold or raise rates if inflation remains elevated (GK86UUQPN); and (3) a recession triggered by a sharper slowdown could force rapid easing (GK86UUQPN). Watch signals for the next three to six months include the Fed’s July and August policy minutes (GK86UUQPN), the passage and funding details of the defense bill in Q4 2025 (O6LHRBLFM), and the August and September labor‑market revisions that will confirm whether the stall‑speed scenario materializes (GK86UUQPN). Confidence in the modest lift scenario is moderate, given the clear fiscal stimulus and Fed signals, but the outcome remains sensitive to policy and labor‑market developments.
